Graphical abstract Harnessing the selectivity in catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 is important for producing valuable chemicals. Herein, the shape dependency of the CO2 hydrogenation on singly dispersed Ru/CeO2 catalysts is investigated. CeO2 of three shapes, including nanocube, nanooctahedron and nanorod, are prepared as the catalyst supports and assigned to the surface of (100), (111) and (110) crystal plane, respectively. The Ru/CeO2 (nanorod) exhibits the highest selectivity to CO (97.6 %) at 350 °C, while the Ru/CeO2 (nanocube) exhibits a mediocre selectivity to CO (41.4 %) but the highest CO2 conversion. The shape of the CeO2 support determines the electronic state of supported Ru atoms through the electronic metal-support interaction. The low CO affinity on cationic Ruβ sites leads to the higher selectivity to CO on the Ru/CeO2 (nanorod) and Ru/CeO2 (nanooctahedron) catalysts, while the strong dissociation ability of H2 on low valence Ruα sites results in the high activity on the Ru/CeO2 (nanocube) catalyst. Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Ceria Shape effect Ruthenium Electronic metal-support interaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The chemical routes to convert CO2 into value-added fuels and chemicals such as formic acid, methanol, dimethyl ether and low-carbon olefins have attracted much attention currently [1–3]. However, it is still a challenge to directly utilize CO2 to generate value-added products in current chemical industry, whereas the most chemicals are produced from CO and H2 (synthetic gas) [4,5]. Therefore, CO is considered as a potential bridge chemical intermediate to introduce CO2 into the carbon cycle economy without changing current industry significantly [1,6–11]. Unfortunately, over a wide temperature range, the reaction of CO2 conversion to CO (reverse water gas reaction, RWGS reaction: CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O, ΔH0 298K = 41.2 kJ/mol) is often accompanied by the side reaction with production of CH4 (CO2 methanation, Sabatier reaction: CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O, ΔH0 298K = -165 kJ/mol), which is not conducive for the conversion of CO2 effectively [12]. Thus, extensive efforts have been dedicated to design catalysts with high selectivity to CO and low selectivity to CH4 [13–17]. The essential is to understand the correlation between the catalyst structure and catalytic performance. Supported metal catalysts have been widely studied in CO2 hydrogenation due to their outstanding catalytic activity. Especially, singly dispersed catalysts featured with atomic dispersed metal sites not only maximize atomic utilization efficiency, but also provide unique electronic properties and geometric structures [18–22]. The development of singly dispersed precious metal catalysts has attracted much attention. Kwak et al [23] found that atomic dispersed Ru atoms on Al2O3 exhibited high CO selectivity and achieved the lowest CO2 conversion compared to Ru nanoparticles. Aitbekov et al [24] reached the similar conclusion during the dynamic transformation of Ru nanoparticles into atomically dispersed Ru on CeO2. Despite it has been revealed that the catalytic performance between nanoparticles and single atom catalyst are distinct due to the different structure of the catalyst, the impact of electronic state of singly dispersed sites to catalysis has not been fully studied. Reducible oxide not only serves as supports for active metals, but also interact with metals in various aspects [25]. CeO2 has been widely studied due to its facile synthesis method, controllable morphology, specific morphology exposure corresponding to specific crystal planes and the specific physical and chemical properties of each crystal surface [26–32]. Ye et al [33] prepared single atoms Pt loaded on rod-shaped CeO2 as a catalyst to investigate the interface interaction of Pt-O-Ce. It was found that the difference in Pt-O-Ce bond strength caused single atoms Pt located on the surface of CeO2 to exhibit a zero-valence state (Pt0), while Pt located inside the CeO2 support exhibited a positive valence state (Ptδ+). Shen et al [34] found that compared to single atoms Pt catalysts anchored on cube-shaped and nanoparticle-shaped CeO2, the catalyst anchored on rod-shaped CeO2 enhanced the activity of low-temperature dry reforming of methane, which is attributed to the Pt doping effect on the surface of CeO2 (110), resulting in the greatly reduction of the formation energy of oxygen vacancies. Jiang et al [35] used the CeO2 crystal plane effect to investigate the stability mechanism of single Pt atoms. These work suggest that the difference in metal-support interactions leading to different degrees of Pt-O-Ce bond distortion at the interface is a key factor in the stability difference. Therefore, understanding the support crystal plane effect to regulate catalytic performance and construct precise structure–activity relationships at the atomic level is a worthwhile research topic, which will help to accurately design catalysts with superior performance. Many factors influence the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation, including the natural of the catalytic metal, the metal dispersion, support redox properties, promoter effect and the metal support interaction. In this work, we focus on the shape dependency of the singly dispersed Ru catalysts supported on ceria of nanocube, nanooctahedron and nanorod. The shape of the ceria support is the factor of interested in this research. To achieve this goal, we constructed three kinds of model catalysts, namely singly dispersed Ru catalysts on CeO2 supports with distinct shapes to study the role of electronic states of singly dispersed Ru atoms for CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The CeO2 supports of nanocube, nanorod and nanooctahedron were prepared and correlated to the surface crystal facet of (100), (110) and (111) plane, respectively. Ru/CeO2 catalysts with different shapes exhibit significant differences in CO2 conversion and products distribution. It was found that the crystal plane effect of supports can regulate the electronic state of singly dispersed Ru atoms, resulting in the formation of abundant Ruα sites on Ru/CeO2 (100), while more cationic Ruβ sites on Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110), respectively. The Ruα sites refers to the lower valence Ru sites on CeO2 surface, while Ruβ sites are the high valence Ru cations doped on the CeO2 surface lattice. The Ruβ active sites with weak affinity for CO leads to high CO selectivity on Ru/CeO2 (110). However, the weak H2 dissociation ability leads to its lower activity. Nevertheless, in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy reveals that the synergistic effect between surface hydroxyl and oxygen vacancies in peripheral active regions near singly dispersed Ru atoms promotes the conversion of reaction intermediates. These findings shed a light to understand the role of electronic metal support interaction in CO2 hydrogenation and provide insight for the catalyst design. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Chemical and materials All chemicals were directly used as received without further purification unless noticed. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (AR), NaOH (AR) and NH4OH (AR) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemicals. RuCl3·xH2O (reagent grade) was purchased from Aladdin Chemicals. Gases were purchased from Fuzhou Huaxinda Industrial Gas Co. Ltd. The purities are noted as following: H2 (99.99 vol%), Ar (99.99 vol%), CO2 (99.999 vol%). 2.2 Catalyst preparation (1) CeO2 supports of various shapes were synthesized based on the reported hydrothermal methods [26,27]. The CeO2 supports of nanocube, nanorod and nanooctahedron were prepared, which were further correlated to the surface facet of (100), (110) and (111) planes as demonstrated by comprehensive characterizations and literatures [26,27]. As for CeO2 (100) and CeO2 (110), a 0.39 M Ce(NO3)3 solution was added dropwise to a 6.89 M solution of NaOH. The above mixed solution was stirred vigorously for 1 h at room temperature (RT, 298 K). Then, it was transferred into a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave with a Teflon liner and hydrothermally heated for 24 h at 180 °C for CeO2 (nanocube) and at 100 °C for CeO2 (nanorod). After the hydrothermal treatment, the precipitates were washed with deionized water until the measured pH of water was close to 7.0. Subsequently, it was dried in a static oven at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C in air for 2 h (ramping rate: 2 °C/min) in a muffle furnace. As for CeO2 (111), a 0.39 M Ce(NO3)3 solution added dropwise to 0.28 M solution of NaOH. The above mixed solution was stirred vigorously for 1 h at room temperature. Then it was transferred into a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave with a Teflon liner and hydrothermally heated for 24 h at 190 °C for CeO2 (nanooctahedron). After the hydrothermal treatment, the precipitates were washed with deionized water until the measured pH of water was close to 7.0. Subsequently, it was dried in a static oven at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h (ramping rate: 2 °C/min) in a muffle furnace. (2) Preparation Ru/CeO2 catalysts. The Ru catalysts supported on CeO2 with various shapes were synthesized using a deposition precipitation method [36,37]. The nominal loading of Ru metal on these catalysts were designed to be 0.2 wt%. A certain amount of RuCl3·xH2O was dissolved in 20 mL water in a glass bottle and ultrasound for 20 min. CeO2 (1.0 g) was dispersed in 80 mL deionized water with violent agitation. The RuCl3 solution (5.0 mg, 0.3 mg/mL) was added to the suspension of dispersed CeO2 through a syringe pump. The above mixed solution was slowly adjusted pH to 9.0 with ammonium hydroxide solution (0.1 mol/L) and continuously stirred for 12 h. Then, the obtained liquid was centrifuged and washed the sediment by deionized water several times. Subsequently, the sediment was dried in a static oven at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C in air for 3 h (2 °C/min) in a muffle furnace. According to the shapes of ceria, the nanocube, nanooctahedron and nanorod sample could also be denoted as Ru/CeO2 (100), Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110), respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization High resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) images and high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) images in Fig. S1 were obtained on the Talos F200s G2 field emission perspective electron microscope (FEI, USA) with an acceleration voltage of 200 KV. The chemical composition was tested using the FEI Super-X energy dispersion spectroscopy (EDX) system. Aberration-corrected high-angle annual dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) images in Fig. 1 , S2 and S3 were obtained by a JEM-ARM300F2 (JEOL, Japan) microscope. The investigation of X-ray absorption spectrum (XAS) on the Ru K-edge were performed using a Si (311) double crystal monochromator in the BL-01B1 of SPring-8 (Japan) and BL-11B of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF, China). All the XAS experiments were recorded under fluorescence mode at RT. The catalyst after reaction were collected and pressed into a pellet with a diameter of 7.0 or 10.0 mm for measurement. The photon energy was calibrated by the absorption edge (E0) of the Ru foil to 22117 eV, where the E0 is defined as the first maximum of the first order derivatives of the XAS spectrum in the energy space. The data was processed and analyzed by the standard protocol using the Athena and Artemis program (version Demeter 0.9.26) [38]. In the fitting of the Fourier transformed (FT) EXAFS spectrum, the data from the k range of 2.7–10.0 Å−1 and the r range of 1.0–3.0 Å was used. The coordination number (CN), distance (Å) and the Debye-Waller factor (σ2) were set as the fitting variables. The amplitude reduction factor (So 2) was set as 0.69 according to the fitting result of the spectrum of Ru foil by assuming the CN of the first shell Ru-Ru is 12. All the FT-EXAFS spectra are plotted without phase correction. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed on a Rigaku Smartlab diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 35 kV and 25 mA. Scan angle was between 5°-90° with a scanning rate of 5 °/min. The obtained data was analyzed by Jade software, then referenced with the corresponding standard card (JCPDS) to obtain the structure information of the catalyst. The actual loading of metal Ru on CeO2 was measured by iCAP 7000 series spectrometer (ICP-OES, Thermo-Fisher, USA). An ASAP 2020 plus (Micromeritics, USA) instrument was used to analyze the surface areas and pore structure of catalysts at 77 K. XPS spectra were obtained on an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo-Fischer, ESCALAB 250Xi, USA) with Al Kα radiation (hv = 1486.6 eV; voltage, 12.5 kV; emission current, 16 mA). The reported binding energies were corrected by referencing to C 1 s (284.8 eV) of environmental carbon. The surface element ratio was evaluated by the spectrum intensity and atomic sensitive factors [39,40]. Raman spectra were used to characterize oxygen vacancies and metal structures on the surface of catalysts. The test was conducted on a DXR2xi micro Raman spectrometer (Thermo-Fisher Scientific, USA) with a 532 nm laser source. The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) profiles were recorded in an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micrometrics, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the H2-TPR, 0.2 g of fresh catalyst was loaded into a quartz tube reactor followed by pretreated in He gas at 300 °C for 2 h and then cooling to 30 °C. Afterwards, the temperature was increased to 800 °C at 10 °C/min under 10 vol% H2/Ar gas mixture. In the CO2-TPD, CO-TPD and H2-TPD experiments, 0.2 g of fresh catalyst was firstly pre-reduced at 400 °C for 2 h with a 10 vol% H2/Ar mixture and then cooled to 30 °C. Subsequently, the catalysts were saturated under 10 vol% CO2/Ar, 10 vol% CO/Ar or 10 vol% H2/Ar flow for 1 h. The gas flow was switched to pure He for 1 h to remove physisorbed CO2, CO or H2 molecules. Then, the temperature was ramped from 30 °C to 800 °C (10 °C/min). The gaseous component was analyzed by TCD detector. Volumetric CO chemisorption analyses were carried out on a MicrotracBEL (MicrotracBEL, Japan) instrument. Catalysts were first reduced at 400 °C for 1 h in a 10 vol% H2/Ar atmosphere. Subsequently, it was switched to Ar flow at 400 °C for 1 h and then naturally cooled to 50 °C for CO chemical adsorption. To measure the dispersion of Ru from the amount of chemically adsorbed CO, it is assumed that the stoichiometry between Ru and CO is 1:1. In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (in situ FTIR) experiments were performed on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with a ZnSe window and MCT detector. For diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy of adsorbed CO (DRIFT-CO) experiments, a certain amount of CeO2 or Ru/CeO2 catalyst was pre-reduced by 5 vol% H2/Ar (20 mL/min) for 2 h at 400 °C. Then it was naturally cooled to room temperature in reducing atmosphere and purged by pure Ar for 2 h. After a stable baseline was collected by the OMNIC spectra software, 5 vol% CO/Ar was introduced to the sample cell. After CO desorption saturation in an Ar atmosphere, a temperature programmed desorption experiment was conducted, where each temperature point remained stable for one hour. For in situ FTIR of CO2 hydrogenation reactions, a certain amount of Ru/CeO2 catalyst was pre-reduced by 5 vol% H2/Ar (20 mL/min) for 2 h at 400 °C. Then it was naturally cooled to relevant temperature in reducing atmosphere and purged by pure Ar for 2 h until no H2 in the pipeline. After a stable baseline was collected the OMNIC spectra software, the relevant reaction gas was injected into the sample cell. When using DRIFT-CO and FTIR spectra to quantitatively analyze the ratio of Ruα and Ruβ sites, we reasonably assume that the difference in molar extinction coefficients between different valence states of singly dispersed Ru atoms is subtle. This difference will not affect the accuracy of the fitting results. 2.4 Catalytic activity CO2 hydrogenation reactions over the Ru/CeO2 catalysts were carried out on a fixed bed reactor with a quartz tube (inner diameter of 6.0 mm) under atmospheric pressure. In a typical test, 16.9 mg catalyst (40–60 mesh) and 300.0 mg quartz sand (20–40 mesh) was mixed and loaded into the reactor. The samples were initially reduced at 400 °C for 2 h in 5 vol% H2 balanced with Ar. Composition of the gas mixture of CO2 and H2 was set at 3 vol% CO2/9 vol% H2/Ar (total 40 mL/min) in the catalytic performance evaluation. The CO2 hydrogenation reactions activity were measured at 350 °C under 142 L·gcat −1·h−1 weight hourly space velocity (WHSV). The mass transfer and heat transfer are discussed in the Note S1 in the Supplementary Material. Finally, the concentrations of reaction and product gases were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014), with TCD detector detecting CO2, CO and H2, with FID detector detecting CH4. CO2 conversion ( X CO 2 ) was calculated as follow: (1) X C O 2 % = [ CO 2 ] in - CO 2 out CO 2 in × 100 % where [ CO 2 ] in and [ CO 2 ] out are the molar concentration of reaction gas CO2 at inlet and outlet. CO selectivity ( S CO ) and CH4 selectivity ( S CH 4 ) were calculated as follow: (2) S C O % = [ C O ] out C O out + CH 4 out × 100 % (3) S C H 4 % = [ CH 4 ] out C O out + CH 4 out × 100 % where [ CH 4 ] out and [ C O ] out are the molar concentration of product gas CH4 and CO outlet. CO yield ( Y CO ) and CH4 yield ( Y CH 4 ) were calculated as follow: (4) Y C O % = [ C O ] out CO 2 in × 100 % (5) Y C H 4 % = [ CH 4 ] out CO 2 in × 100 % Turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated as follow: (6) T O F ( min - 1 ) = V CO 2 V m ∙ X CO 2 m cat ∙ w Ru M Ru ∙ D Ru where V CO 2 is the inlet volumetric flow rate of CO2, V m =22.4 L/mol, mcat is the weight of catalysts (g), wRu is the actual weight percentage of Ru (wt%) measured by ICP-OES, MRu is the molar mass of Ru (g/mol), DRu is the actual dispersion of Ru (%). The value of TOF on each sample was calculated based on CO2 conversion below 15 % at 350 °C. Activity was calculated as follow: (7) A c t i v i t y ( mmol CO 2 ∙ g Ru - 1 ∙ s - 1 ) = V CO 2 V m ∙ X CO 2 m cat ∙ w Ru The apparent activation energy barrier (Ea) was determined by Arrhenius equation: (8) k = A e - ( E a RT ) where k is the rate of reaction (d−1), A is the pre-exponential factor, Ea is the activation energy of the reaction (kJ/mol), R is the gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1) and T is the temperature (K). An Arrhenius plot of ln(rate) versus 1/T was analyzed to obtain the Ea [39,41]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The exposed surface crystal lattice plane of Ru/CeO2 catalysts of different shapes The morphology, major exposed crystal planes and state of Ru atoms of Ru/CeO2 catalysts after reaction were investigated by HR-TEM and AC-HAADF-STEM. Three morphologies of CeO2 are successfully synthesized by hydrothermal method and remain unchanged during the reaction (Fig. S1a-c1). As shown in Fig. S1a1, the Ru/CeO2 (100) sample exhibts cube shaped nanoparticles. The clear lattice fringe spacing on its surface is 0.27 nm, corresponding to the (100) plane of CeO2 (Fig. S1a2), which is consistent with the literature [27,35,42]. Nevertheless, the Ru/CeO2 (111) sample is made up of octahedron shaped nanoparticles (Fig. S1b1), which exposes (111) plane of CeO2 with a lattice spacing of 0.31 nm (Fig. S1b2) [26,35]. Moreover, the Ru/CeO2 (110) sample in Fig. S1c1 shows the morphology of nanorod. Due to the observation of a large number of exposes sides (110) (Fig. S1c2) and combined with literatures [27,41–43], it is concluded that the nanorod like CeO2 is mainly exposed with CeO2 (110) crystal planes. In the HR-TEM (Fig. S1a-c2) and HAADF-STEM images (Fig. S1a-c3), the lattice fringes of Ru particles or oxide are not detected. The AC-HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 1 and S2) shows that the shape and exposed crystal planes of CeO2 supports are the same as those of HR-TEM image (Fig. S1). It is obvious that Ru atoms exist as single atoms on CeO2, displayed in red circles in Fig. 1a-c2. The Ru atoms remain in a singly dispersed state (Fig. S2). The small particles of Ru are not found in the EDX images (Fig. S3). Furthermore, the catalysts were attempted for the X-ray absorption spectrum (XAS) to demonstrate the electronic state and coordination state of Ru atoms/cations. As shown in Fig. S4 and discussed in Note S2, no evidence is found for the formation of Ru-Ru coordination path. In other words, it is hinted that the Ru are highly dispersed in the catalyst after reaction. The singly dispersion of Ru in one sample, the Ru/CeO2 (110) catalyst after reaction, is confirmed by the FT-EXAFS data and the fitting results (Fig. S4f and Table S1). Moreover, the distinct XANES structure of Ru K-edge in the catalysts suggests the electronic state maybe different (Fig. S4a), which will be further investigated and discussed in the following sections. Crystalline structure of pure CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 catalysts were further studied by XRD. All samples exhibit well-resolved diffraction patterns (Fig. 2 ). There is no significant change in the diffraction pattern throughout the entire reaction process. The peaks at 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.6°, 56.4°, 59.2°, 69.4° and 76.7° are attributed to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (311) and (420) lattice fringes of CeO2 with the face-centered cubic structure (JCPDS: PDF#34–0394), respectively. Diffraction peak intensity of different shapes CeO2 are consistent with those reported in literatures [27,41,44]. No characteristic peaks of Ru or RuOx species are observed in Fig. 2, which could be ascribed to the low loading of the Ru or the well dispersed Ru species on the different CeO2 surface [10]. The size of CeO2 crystallite gain is calculated based on the FWHM at 28.6° through the Scherrer equation, as shown in Table 1 . The actual loading amount of Ru on the three samples surface are consistent with the nominal values (Table 1). Moreover, CO chemisorption experiments results show that the Ru dispersion on three CeO2 support are as high as 99.9 %, which proves that the Ru species are singly dispersed on CeO2 (Fig. S5). Specific surface area and pore structure of pure CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 catalysts were determined via nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm with Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method. The specific surface area of Ru/CeO2 (100), (111) and (110) catalysts is 19, 63 and 99 m2/g, respectively, which is conforming to the trend that smaller nanoparticles with larger surface area [45]. Compared with the specific surface area of pure CeO2 supports with distinct shapes (20, 66 and 103 m2/g), no obvious change is observed after loading Ru. The adsorption–desorption isotherm diagram (Fig. S6a) shows that the Ru/CeO2 (100) sample is featured for a type IV adsorption isotherm with mesoporous structure and belongs to the H3 type hysteresis loop [46]. The pore size is around 20 nm, which is due to the stacking of CeO2 nanocubes (Fig. S6b). However, Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110) samples have type IV adsorption isotherm (Fig. S6a) with mesoporous structure and belong to H1 hysteresis loop [47], and their pore sizes are concentrated around 7 nm and 12 nm, respectively (Fig. S6b). 3.2 The shape dependency in CO2 hydrogenation performance Firstly, the mass and heat transfer limitations under this reaction condition are discussed in the Note S1 in Supplementary Material, which demonstrate that the measured CO and CH4 reaction rates are intrinsic and kinetic controlled. As shown in the Fig. S7a-b, there is the catalytic performance of prepared catalysts over different reaction temperature (200–350 °C). The pure CeO2 support shows no activity under this reaction condition (Fig. S7a). As the temperature increases, the activities of Ru/CeO2 catalysts with different shapes also increases. The Ru/CeO2 (100) shows the highest activity consistently (Fig. S7b). During the reaction test, the CO selectivity undergoes changes (Fig. S7c), indicating differences in the main reaction pathway of the same catalyst at different reaction stages. Secondly, the intrinsic activity of three catalysts based on product distribution were evaluated. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the turnover frequency toward CO ( T O F C O ) values over Ru/CeO2 (100), Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110) catalysts are 21.1, 24.2 and 30.6 min−1, respectively. The TOF toward CH4 ( T O F C H 4 ) values are 35.5, 16.5 and 3.3 min−1, respectively. The Ru/CeO2 (100) catalyst shows the highest TOF with the highest selectivity to CH4, while the Ru/CeO2 (110) catalyst shows the lowest TOF but the highest selectivity to CO, indicating that the reactivities to generate CO and CH4 are different on these three catalysts. Afterwards, the actual catalytic performance of each catalyst was tested. The activity of each catalyst is stable during the reaction process (Fig. 3b). The Ru/CeO2 (100) catalyst shows the highest activity, while Ru/CeO2 (110) has the lowest activity. It is worth noting that the Ru/CeO2 (100) catalyst with the highest activity has the minimum CO selectivity (41.4 %) (Fig. S7d) and the highest H2 conversion (20.0 %) (Fig. S7e), while Ru/CeO2 (110) shows the opposite trend, indicating that catalysts with strong H2 dissociation ability are more likely to generate CH4. After conducting a cycle, the activity and CO selectivity of each catalyst remain basically unchanged (Fig. S7f-g), which means that the active site remains unchanged throughout the reaction. The CO selectivity also shows significant differences at the similiar CO2 conversion level, 96.8 % for Ru/CeO2 (110), 63.9 % for Ru/CeO2 (111) and 41.4 % for Ru/CeO2 (100), respectively (Fig. S7h and 3c). Moreover, under the similar mass of the catalyst, the selectiviy to CO on Ru/CeO2(110) is 97.6%. These results indicate that CeO2 with different shapes can indeed regulate the selectivity of singly dispersed Ru atoms in CO2 hydrogenation. Afterwards, the changes in catalyst performance under different weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) by changing the gas flow rate were investigated. As the WHSV decreases, the CO selectivity (Fig. 3d) of Ru/CeO2 (100) and Ru/CeO2 (111) catalysts decreases significantly. The products distribution of CO2 hydrogenation on Ru/CeO2 (110) is little affected by changes in WHSV. This observation suggests that CO is a key intermediate for CO2 methanation on three catalysts [48,49]. In order to explore the fundamental originations of different shapes Ru/CeO2 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation reactions, the apparent activation energy barriers (Ea) of CO and CH4 generation were measured. There is no significant difference in Ea calculated based on the CO generation rate (Fig. 3e), but the Ea calculated based on the CH4 generation rate is significantly different (Fig. 3f), which proves that the main activity difference is determined by the step of generation of CH4. As the contrast, the Ea of CO or CH4 generation on the Ru nanoparticles catalysts are relatively similar (Fig. S7i-j), indicating the uniqueness of this research system. Therefore, it is hypothesized that the reaction routes toward CO and CH4 are parallel and independent [50]. The route to CH4 is more influenced by the reaction temperature since the Ea is larger. 3.3 The shape dependency of surface element and chemical properties on Ru supported on CeO2 Surface elemental composition and chemical states of the Ru/CeO2 catalysts were studied using XPS. Considering that Ru 3d overlaps with C 1s, Ru 3p spectra were collected to analyze Ru species [41]. Because of the strong C 1s spectral signal, the region of Ru 3d is highlighted in the C 1s spectra (Fig. 4 a). In the Ru 3p3/2 spectra (Fig. 4b), the characteristic peaks of reduced Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110) samples are weaker than that of reduced Ru/CeO2 (100). Due to the same testing conditions (number of scanning cycles and sample dosage), it is preliminarily determined that the reason for the difference in spectra signals is the content and state of surface Ru atoms. ICP-OES results show that the actual loading of the three catalysts is almost the same. Therefore, we believe that the main reason is the different states of singly dispersed Ru atoms. The Ru 3p3/2 spectra of all samples can be deconvoluted into two peaks, which are attributed to low valence Ruα (461.8 eV) and cationic Ruβ (464.4 eV) [41,51], which will be further examined by in situ FTIR and DRIFT-CO spectroscopy. Here the Ruα sites are considered to be reduced Ru atoms exposed on CeO2 surface, while Ruβ sites are considered to be Ru atoms doped on CeO2 lattice. From the quantitative XPS analysis results in Table 2 , the Ruα/(Ruα + Ruβ) ratio of reduced Ru/CeO2 (100) is 55.7 %, while the ratio decreased to 51.2 % and 50.2 % on reduced Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110). Moreover, the Ru/Ce ratio on reduced Ru/CeO2 decreases in the same order, 0.54 % for Ru/CeO2 (100), 0.34 % for Ru/CeO2 (111) and 0.31 % for Ru/CeO2 (110), respectively. This proves that electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI) is pronounced for reduced Ru/CeO2 (100) and Ru/CeO2 (111), resulting in the formation of RuxCe1-xO2-d solid solution to a greater extent and less Ru species on the surface. EMSI is considered as a type of metal-support interaction (MSI) [25]. The charge can be transferred through the interface between the metal and the support. A large amount of studies have shown that the support crystal plane effect regulates the electronic structure of single atoms by changing the strength of EMSI [17,35,52]. After the reaction (Fig. S8a), the Ruα ratio on the surface of used Ru/CeO2 (100) catalyst remains the highest. The surface Ru/Ce values are 0.64 % for Ru/CeO2 (100), 0.33 % for Ru/CeO2 (111) and 0.27 % for Ru/CeO2 (110), respectively (Table S2). Therefore, it is believed that the state of Ru atoms on the surface of the catalysts after the reaction is highly consistent with that before the reaction. This indicates that the electronic state of singly dispersed Ru atoms are regulated by the EMSI effect on the CeO2 (100), (111) and (110) crystal planes, resulting in a higher content of Ruα on the CeO2 (100) crystal plane and a higher content of Ruβ on the CeO2 (111) and (110) crystal planes. Subsequently, the valence states of singly dispersed Ru atoms were further accurately investigated through DRIFT-CO and in situ FTIR spectroscopy. The Ce 3d spectra of Ru/CeO2 catalysts surface after reduction are shown in Fig. 4c. Each spectrum can be fitted into ten peaks. The six peaks at u''' (916.4 eV), u'' (907.1 eV), u (900.5 eV), v''' (897.9 eV), v'' (888.6 eV) and v (882.1 eV) belonged to Ce4+ species. The four peaks at u' (902.6 eV), u0 (898.9 eV), v' (884.5 eV) and v0 (880.1 eV) are assigned to Ce3+ species [53,54]. Generally, when Ce4+ is reduced to Ce3+, oxygen vacancies are generated due to charge balance [21,55]. Ratio of Ce3+/(Ce4++Ce3+) was calculated quantitatively. The highest Ce3+ content on the surface of reduced Ru/CeO2 (110) is 32.9 % (Table 2), implying that the reduced Ru/CeO2 (110) catalyst surface has the highest oxygen vacancy concentration. The oxygen species on the surface of reduced Ru/CeO2 catalysts were studied by O 1s spectra. As shown in Fig. 4d, the spectra of all samples can be fitted into two peaks. The first peak at 531.3 eV is attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oads), which is composed of surface hydroxyl (–OH) and carbonate (CO3 2–) groups [37,40,41]. The other peak at 529.1 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen (Olatt) [56,57]. It is reported that the hydroxyl groups on the surface of CeO2 can be used as Lewis-basic sites to adsorb and activate CO2 [43,58]. The relative content of hydroxyl groups on the surface of reduced Ru/CeO2 was calculated quantitatively. First, the molar ratio of Oads/(Oads + Olatt) on the surface was calculated, where each symbol corresponds to its peak area. The values are 29.7 % for reduced Ru/CeO2 (100), 28.8 % for reduced Ru/CeO2 (111) and 30.7 % for reduced Ru/CeO2 (110), respectively. According to the literature [53], the relative content of CO3 2– was calculated based on CO3 2–/(CO3 2–+C), where CO3 2– represents the peak area of CO3 2– (288.7 eV) and C represents the peak area of C (284.8 eV) in the C 1s spectra of Fig. 4a. As shown in Table 2, there are 23.5, 22.0 and 20.7 %, respectively. Therefore, the ratio of –OH are 6.2 % for reduced Ru/CeO2 (100), 6.8 % for reduced Ru/CeO2 (111) and 10.7 % for reduced Ru/CeO2 (110), respectively, verifying that the Ru/CeO2 (110) surface has the highest amount of hydroxyl groups. The results were further proved in CO2-TPD and in situ FTIR experiments. Relative content of surface oxygen vacancies on the reduced Ru/CeO2 catalysts and the strength of the interaction between the metal and the support were further verified through Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S9). All samples show a strong peak at 460 cm−1 belonging to the symmetric vibrational mode of lattice oxygen on CeO2 (F2g), a weak defect-induced mode (D) peak at 597 cm−1 [60,61]. The ratio of the intensity of the D peak to the F2g peak is usually used to semi quantitatively calculate the density of oxygen vacancies on the surface of CeO2. After calculation, the I D / I F 2 g values of reduced Ru/CeO2 (110) (0.088) is greater than both reduced Ru/CeO2 (111) (0.072) and reduced Ru/CeO2 (100) (0.084). This result indicates that the oxygen vacancy density on reduced Ru/CeO2 (110) is the highest, which is consistent with the XPS results. The small peak at 972 cm−1 belongs to the vibrational of the Ru-O-Ce bond. The ratio of the Ru-O-Ce peak to the F2g intensity is usually used to measure the relative density of interfacial bonding [60,62]. The I R u - O - C e / I F 2 g ratio decreases according to reduced Ru/CeO2 (110), Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (100), with 0.052, 0.048 and 0.031, respectively. Further evidence suggests that the crystal plane effect leads to a stronger effect of CeO2 (110) support on surface Ru atoms, while CeO2 (100) support has a weaker effect on surface Ru atoms. The redox property of pure CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 samples were investigated through H2-TPR. For pure CeO2 supports (Fig. S10), each sample exhibits two characteristic reduction peaks. The low-temperature peaks are belonged to the reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+, which is often accompanied by the generation of surface oxygen vacancies. The high-temperature peaks are belonged to the reduction of sub surface bulk CeO2 [63]. CeO2 (110) is more easily reduced, resulting in a large number of oxygen vacancies on the surface after reduction. Ru/CeO2 samples exhibit more complex reduction curve (Fig. 5 a). Specifically, the first reduction peak (about 80 °C) can be ascribed to the reduction of Ruβ on Ru/CeO2 surface, the second reduction peak (about 110 °C) can be ascribed to the reduction of Ruβ in RuxCe1-xO2-d, the third reduction peak (about 190 °C) can be ascribed to the reduction of oxygen adsorbed on oxygen vacancy, the fourth reduction peak (about 400 °C) can be ascribed to the reduction of CeO2 support surface [32,53,64]. Reduction of Ru species on CeO2 (110) requires the highest amount of H2 and the highest reduction temperature. These conditions are exactly opposite on Ru/CeO2 (100), which proves that the EMSI intensity in Ru/CeO2 catalyst decreases in the order of Ru/CeO2 (110), Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (100), in consistent with XPS and Raman results. Based on the above analysis, it can be summarized that CeO2 (100), (111) and (110) exhibits different EMSI strength on singly dispersed Ru atoms by the proof of the intensity of Ru 3p3/2 spectra and surface Ru/Ce ratio in XPS, the ratio of Ru-O-Ce signal to F2g signal in Raman spectra. The reduction temperature of Ru species in H2-TPR curve indicate that the EMSI intensity is weakest on Ru/CeO2 (100), resulting in more Ruα sites on Ru/CeO2 (100) and more Ruβ sites on Ru/CeO2 (110). In addition, the O 1s spectra in XPS and the signal ratio of the D and F2g peaks in Raman spectra indicates that the surface hydroxyl and nonstoichiometric oxygen sites (adsorb CO2 to form carbonate) concentrations on Ru/CeO2 (110) are the highest. 3.4 The shape dependency of adsorption and desorption of reactants and products Dissociation ability of Ru/CeO2 catalysts for H2 were tested through H2-TPD experiments. As shown in Fig. 5b, the dissociation peaks above 350 °C are attributed to H2 adsorbed on CeO2 support, where the H atoms spillover from Ru atoms onto the support [32]. No desorption peak of H atoms adsorbed on Ru atoms is found below 350 °C, indicating weak adsorption of H atoms by singly dispersed Ru atoms and causing H atoms to easily spillover to the interface between Ru atoms and CeO2. CO2 adsorption and activation of reactants on Ru/CeO2 catalysts were investigated through CO2-TPD experiments. All samples show three desorption peaks (Fig. 5c), which can be attributed to weak adsorption sites (below 200 °C), medium adsorption sites (200–450 °C) and strong adsorption sites (above 450 °C) [43,53]. In general, weak adsorption sites are related to surface hydroxyl groups, while medium adsorption sites are related to surface oxygen vacancies. Moreover, increasing the quantity of weak adsorption sites and medium adsorption sites for CO2 can promote CO2 hydrogenation performance [65,66]. The quantitative analysis of CO2 adsorption is shown in Table 3 . Based on each gram of catalyst, the weak adsorption sites amount are 1.38 m m o l C O 2 · gcat −1 for Ru/CeO2 (100), 6.14 m m o l C O 2 · gcat −1 for Ru/CeO2 (111) and 14.06 m m o l C O 2 · gcat −1 for Ru/CeO2 (110), respectively. The amount of medium adsorption sites increases in the same order, 0.04, 0.37 and 1.25 m m o l C O 2 · gcat −1, respectively. However, there is no correlation observed between the CO2 adsorption sequence and catalytic performance (Fig. 3b). Therefore, it is reasonable to speculate that the adsorption of CO2 or specific surface area may not be a rate determine factor in the catalytic activity of this experiment. CO, as an important intermediate in CO2 hydrogenation reaction, hence, it is essential to reveal its desorption differences on Ru/CeO2 catalysts through CO-TPD experiments. In Fig. 5d, the peaks below 200 °C are attributed to the CO dissociation peak adsorbed on the Ru species, while the peaks above 200 °C are attributed to the CO dissociation peak adsorbed on the CeO2 support [67]. It is observed that the dissociation peak of CO adsorbed on the Ru atoms on the surfaces of Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110) catalysts are similar (98 °C and 93 °C) and very weak, while it has not only stronger intensity but also relatively higher dissociation temperatures (114 °C) on Ru/CeO2 (100), which indicates that the singly dispersed Ru atoms on CeO2 (100) exhibit stronger affinity with CO. Based on the selectivity of the actual products of the three catalysts (Fig. S7d), the Ru/CeO2 (100) catalyst produces a large amount of CH4 (58.6 %), while the Ru/CeO2 (110) catalyst generates almost 97.6 % of CO. It is reasonable to infer that the strength of the Ru atoms on CeO2 for CO adsorption determines the distribution of CO2 hydrogenation products. If the metal-CO* bond is strong, CO* will be kept on the Ru site and further hydrogenated to generate CH4 instead of desorbing to CO. Similar conclusions have been verified in other research work [50,68]. The state of Ru with adsorbed CO on different crystal planes Ru/CeO2 catalysts was further investigated through DRIFT-CO experiments. Specific operation steps were described in the catalyst characterization section. First, we tested DRIFT-CO of pure CeO2 supports. As shown in Fig. S11, only CO (gas) infrared peaks (2170 and 2110 cm−1) are observed on CeO2 (100) and CeO2 (111) in the range of 2300–1800 cm−1 at room temperature (RT) (Fig. S11a-b). Other physical adsorption peaks appeared on CeO2 (110) in the range of 2050–1800 cm−1, but they are easily desorbed by purging (Fig. S11c). Therefore, the chemical adsorption of CO on CeO2 is excluded. Compared with the DRFT-CO spectra of pure CeO2 supports, the CO desorption curve of Ru/CeO2 catalysts show two characteristic peaks in the range of 2300–1950 cm−1 at RT, indicating that the molecule CO is adsorbed on different Ru sites (Fig. 6 ). Specifically, the Ru/CeO2 (100) spectra exhibits characteristic bands at 2043 and 1991 cm−1 (Fig. 6a), the Ru/CeO2 (111) spectra at 2039 and 1966 cm−1 (Fig. 6b) and the Ru/CeO2 (110) spectra at 2036 and 1956 cm−1 (Fig. 6c). The high-frequency band of approximately 2040 cm−1 is accurately attributed to the linear adsorption peak of CO at the low valence Ru atoms sites [62,69], denoted as Ruα-CO. Nevertheless, Chen et al [70] measured a CO adsorption peak of 1980 cm−1 on Ce0.875Ru0.125O2 (111). Sharma et al [71] measured a CO adsorption peak of 1990 cm−1 on Ce0.95Ru0.05O2. They attributed this infrared band to the CO linear adsorption on the Ru sites at the Ru doped CeO2 interface. Therefore, we assign the second low-frequency band located in the range of 2000–1950 cm−1 to the linear bonded CO adsorption peak on the Ru sites at the Ru doped CeO2 interface, denoted as Ruβ-CO, where Ru is in the high valence cationic state. This result indicates that CeO2 (100), (111) and (110) crystal planes regulate the electronic state of singly dispersed Ru atoms by regulating the degree of RuxCe1-xO2-d solid solution formation. Quantitative analysis of various adsorption sites at RT using Gaussian fitting is shown in Table 4 . It is suggested that the Ruα sites shows the highest content on Ru/CeO2 (100) (76.6 %), while the Ruα content is lower on Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110) (39.9 % and 33.4 %, respectively), which further proves that a higher degree of solid solution is formed on Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110), in consistent with the XPS results. After RT desorption saturation, temperature programmed CO desorption experiments were conducted at Ar. When the temperature is risen to 100 °C, the CO adsorption peak on Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110) disappears (Fig. 6b-c). However, the CO adsorption peaks on Ru/CeO2 (100) is not completely disappeared until 200 °C (Fig. 6a). This phenomenon indicates that the Ruα sites exhibit stronger affinity to CO, while the Ruβ sites exhibit weaker affinity to CO. On Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110), the weak affinity for CO leads to the CO adsorbed on the high valence sites desorbed into gas-phase CO, rather than further hydrogenation to produce CH4. On Ru/CeO2 (100), strongly affinity CO* is further hydrogenated to produce CH4 (Fig. S7d). Therefore, we confirm that the adsorption strength of Ruα and Ruβ sites on CO determines the distribution of CO2 hydrogenation products. Based on the above analysis, it is concluded that the state of singly dispersed Ru atoms affects the adsorption and desorption of reactants and products, finally leads to different catalytic performance. The H2-TPD curves indicate that singly dispersed Ru atoms have strong H-spillover ability. The CO-TPD curves and DRIFT-CO spectra suggest that the Ruα sites exhibit stronger affinity for CO compared to the Ruβ sites. In addition, it has been proven that the highest CO2 adsorption sites exists on the Ru/CeO2 (110) surface compared with the lowest CO2 adsorption sites on the Ru/CeO2 (100), which could be correlated to the CO2 hydrogenation performance. 3.5 Mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation on different shapes Ru/CeO2 In order to elucidate the reaction mechanism of Ru/CeO2 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation, the evolution of surface intermediate species was detected by in situ FTIR spectra. Specific operation steps were described in the catalyst characterization section. The peaks position information and references involved in the spectra were summarized in Table S3. In situ FTIR spectra of 1 vol% CO2/Ar adsorption on Ru/CeO2 catalysts with temperature variation are shown in Fig. 7 a-c1. During the temperature rise to 200 °C, the inverted peak of Ce3+–OH (∼3655 cm−1) gradually increases, prove CO2 adsorption on Ce3+–OH to form HCO3* (3624, 1600, 1287 and 1216 cm−1). The order of HCO3* peak intensity is consistent with the weak adsorption intensity of CO2-TPD (Table 3). Interestingly, HCOO* (3590, 2939 and 2847 cm−1), Ru-CO* (2100–1950 cm−1) and CH4 (3016 cm−1) peaks appeared. The peak intensity gradually increases, especially on Ru/CeO2 (100) (Fig. 7a1). This indicates that under the reaction of Ce-H (950 cm−1) bonds (Fig. S12), HCO3* undergoes the HCOO* pathway to produce CO, which is further hydrogenated to produce CH4, as evidenced by the Ce-H inverted peak gradually increases [32,72–74]. Considering the singly dispersed Ru atoms, the amplitude of HCO3* peak intensity (strongest on Ru/CeO2 (110)) and catalytic activity (the peak of CH4 is strongest on Ru/CeO2 (100)) on the three catalysts is inconsistent, indicating that the active region is not the entire CeO2 surface, but a peripheral area the Ru atoms. The Ce-H and partial Ce3+–OH required here are generated by the H atoms obtained from the dissociation of H2 by the Ru atoms during pretreatment. The larger inverted peak areas of Ce-H (Fig. S12a) and Ce3+–OH (Fig. 7a1) on Ru/CeO2 (100) indicate that Ruα sites (Ruα-CO*: 2025 cm−1) on CeO2 (100) have a stronger H2 dissociation ability. As the temperature increases from 200 °C to 350 °C, the peaks intensity of CO and CH4 gradually decreases. It is worth noting that the Ce4+–OH peak gradually increases due to the consumption of oxygen vacancies (Fig. 7a1) [72,75], indicating that oxygen vacancies play a crucial role in the reaction at this stage. In situ FTIR spectra of 1 vol% CO2/3 vol% H2/Ar adsorption were collected on Ru/CeO2 catalysts at different temperatures, as shown in Fig. 7a-c2. Compared with the only CO2 adsorption spectra (Fig. 7a-c1), almost all peaks intensities in the CO2 + H2 spectra increase without significant changes in peaks position, indicating that H2 promotes the reaction to proceed forward without changing the reaction path. It is obvious that there is a significant difference in the adsorption strength of Ru-CO* (2100–1950 cm−1) on the three catalysts, which is precisely due to the strong affinity for CO of the Ruα sites (2030 cm−1) on Ru/CeO2 (100) and the strong dissociation ability for H2 that promotes the generation of the most CH4 (3016 cm−1) (Fig. 7a2). As the temperature increases, the intensity of the CH4 peak changes complexly, indicating that the main mechanisms for producing CH4 are different at each stage. It is worth affirming that Ce3+–OH (∼3652 cm−1) play a crucial role below 200 °C, while oxygen vacancies play a crucial role above 200 °C, as Ce4+–OH (3734 cm−1) is significantly enhanced (Fig. 7a2). The Ruβ sites with weak affinity for CO results in almost no CH4 generation on Ru/CeO2 (110) (Fig. 7c2). The amount of CO and CH4 produced conforms to the actual distribution pattern of reaction products (Fig. S7d). In situ FTIR spectra of 1 vol% CO2/3 vol% H2/Ar adsorption on Ru/CeO2 catalysts at 350 °C on the time of stream are shown in the Fig. 8 a-c. The peaks of HCO3* (∼3621 and 1283 cm−1) and HCOO* (3588, 2948, 2837 and 1590 cm−1) intermediates are strongest on Ru/CeO2 (110) (Fig. 8c), but the peaks of Ru-CO* (2100–1950 cm−1) and CH4 (3016 cm−1) are strongest on Ru/CeO2 (100) (Fig. 8a), indicating that the synergistic effect of surface hydroxyl species and oxygen vacancies around the Ru atoms promotes the conversion of intermediates. We establish a relationship between the peaks fitting of the stable 60 min spectra in the range of 2100–1950 cm−1 and the actual distribution of reaction products (Fig. 3c). As shown in Fig. 8d, there are a strong linear correlation between the types of singly dispersed Ru atomic sites and the distribution of products. The selectivity at the identical quality catalyst mass has a more strong linear relationship with the ratio of Ru atomic sites (Fig. S13). As the ratio of Ruβ sites increases, CO selectivity significantly increases. It should be noted that the ratio of Ruα and Ruβ sites on Ru/CeO2 catalysts fitted by DRIFT-CO spectra at room temperature (Fig. 6) is inconsistent with the in situ FTIR spectra (Fig. 8a-c) fitting results, fully demonstrating the importance of using in situ spectroscopy for catalyst characterization. Chen et al [17] found that the coordination of single atoms Pt with more Ce on CeO2 (cube) mainly forms Pt0, while the coordination of Pt with more O on CeO2 mainly forms Ptδ+. The electronic state of Pt affects the CO oxidation activity. Zhang et al [76] prepared single atoms Ru catalysts on the CeO2 support with different shapes for selective hydrogenation of aromatics. They found that due to the difference of single atoms Ru coordination environment in different CeO2 shapes, Run+, Ru4+and Ru0 active sites will be formed. The electronic state of Ru determines the catalytic activity. Therefore, we believe that in this work, two active sites with varying degree of Ruβ and Ruα are generated on different crystal planes of CeO2. In summary, CeO2 (100), CeO2 (111) and CeO2 (110) supports affect the electronic state of surface singly dispersed Ru atoms, leading to its formation of Ruβ and Ruα sites. The schematic diagram of different shapes Ru/CeO2 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation reaction is shown in Fig. 9 . The Ruβ sites have weak affinity for CO* and dissociative ability for H2, resulting in high CO selectivity and low CO2 conversion, while the Ruα sites have strong affinity for CO* and dissociative ability for H2, resulting in high CH4 selectivity and CO2 conversion. 4 Conclusions In this work, singly dispersed Ru atom catalysts supported on three different shapes of CeO2 (100), (111) and (110) were synthesized to investigate the crystal planes dependency in product distribution, structure–activity relationship and reaction mechanism of these three catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The Ru/CeO2 (100) shows the highest activity (21.9 m m o l C O 2 · g R u - 1 · s - 1 ) and the highest selectivity (58.6 %) for methanation, while the Ru/CeO2 (110) shows the lowest activity (13.1 m m o l C O 2 · g R u - 1 s - 1 ) and highest selectivity (97.6 %) for RWGS reaction. Various physical and chemical properties and reaction mechanism of the Ru/CeO2 catalysts were tested using XRD, HR-TEM, AC-HAADF-STEM, XAS, Raman, XPS, TPD, TPR, DRIFT-CO and in situ FTIR. Results show that the electronic state of singly dispersed Ru atoms can be regulated by the distinct crystal plane of CeO2 through the EMSI effect. More surface suspended low valence Ruα sites are formed on Ru/CeO2 (100), while more Ru cations are doped in CeO2 lattice to form high valence Ruβ sites on Ru/CeO2 (111) and Ru/CeO2 (110). The difference in the EMSI strength is determined by factors such as the defect effect on the surface of each crystal plane and its specific crystal plane essence, which in turn leads to the formation of two distinct states of Ru atoms. There is a strong correlation between the product distribution of reaction and Ruα and Ruβ sites. As the ratio of Ruβ sites increases, the reaction proceeds in the RWGS direction, producing a large amount of CO. As the ratio of Ruα sites increases, the reaction proceeds in the direction of CO2 methanation, producing a large amount of CH4. Results of in situ FTIR testing have shown that weak affinity for CO by the Ruβ sites is the reasons for the generation of a large amount of CO on the Ru/CeO2 (110) catalyst. The strong dissociation ability for H2 by the Ruα sites is the reason for the highest CO2 conversion on the Ru/CeO2 (100) catalyst. In conclusion, reducing the affinity of metal sites for CO will increase RWGS selectivity and enhancing the dissociation ability of metal sites towards H2 will enhance the conversion of CO2. This work reveals the significance of electronic state of singly dispersed catalyst by focusing on the shape dependency of the catalytic activity, which is originated from the EMSI between ceria support and Ru atoms. coredata.dc:description: Harnessing the selectivity in catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 is important for producing valuable chemicals. Herein, the shape dependency of the CO2 hydrogenation on singly dispersed Ru/CeO2 catalysts is investigated. CeO2 of three shapes, including nanocube, nanooctahedron and nanorod, are prepared as the catalyst supports and assigned to the surface of (100), (111) and (110) crystal plane, respectively. The Ru/CeO2 (nanorod) exhibits the highest selectivity to CO (97.6 %) at 350 °C, while the Ru/CeO2 (nanocube) exhibits a mediocre selectivity to CO (41.4 %) but the highest CO2 conversion. The shape of the CeO2 support determines the electronic state of supported Ru atoms through the electronic metal-support interaction. The low CO affinity on cationic Ruβ sites leads to the higher selectivity to CO on the Ru/CeO2 (nanorod) and Ru/CeO2 (nanooctahedron) catalysts, while the strong dissociation ability of H2 on low valence Ruα sites results in the high activity on the Ru/CeO2 (nanocube) catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Shape dependency of CO2 hydrogenation on ceria supported singly dispersed Ru catalysts
